text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, from West 3rd to 4th Streets, showing subway construction. View No. 2 is the
same site at a later date.
In 1939, a playground will be constructed
by the W.P.A. here. The photographer's vantage point is under the "El" curve (demolished 1939) at 3rd Street and he is viewing northeastward towards Washington Square. The "Pepper Pot" is on the south side of 4th Street where
it bears No. 148.
View 1: September 1, 1928
View 2: March 11, 1932
P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - 3rd Street (West).

text:
Sixth Avenue, west side, at the head of West 3rd Street, showing the frontage extending between Carmine (left) and Cornelia (right) Street's. In the foreground is the cleared swath beneath which is the Sixth Avenue
Subway (under construction).
The J. Lamb Eccelesiastical Art Works is at No. 323-5.and in May, 1937 will be converted into a motion picture house, the Waverly Theatre. Views 2 and 3 are linited to this feature and show its relationship to the Sixth Avenue "El" curve at
3rd Street.
Views 1, 2: March 15, 1932
View 3: October 11, 1928
P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - 3rd Street (West).

text:
Sixth Avenue, north from West 3rd Street, showing buildings on the westerly side, the "El" structure in the center and the subway clearance on the east.  At the left is the tall triangular loft building at the apex formed with Cornelia Street. (2 Cornelia St.)  To the north is an apartment building at Waverly Place.  Beyond is the tower of the Jefferson Market Court.

Views 2 and 3 are limited showing mainly the aforementioned loft building.  In the foreground is a subway excavation at the S.E. corner of 3rd Street.  Note at the left margin the Ecclesiastical Art Works at No. 323-5 Sixth Avenue.  Subsequently this structure will be converted into the Waverly Theatre.

The photographer's vantage point is the roof-top of No. 24 Minetta Lane.

October 11, 1928
Views 1,2,3
P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - 3rd Street (West).

text:
1
North on Sixth Avenue from N.E. corner of 3rd Street. Building with clock in left background is Jefferson Market Court,
on site of old Jefferson Market.
P.L.Sperr,Photographer.  March 11, 1932.

2
Looking North on Sixth Avenue from 3rd Street.
February 20, 1932.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

1
North on Sixth Avenue from N.E. corner of 3rd Street. Building with clock in left background is Jefferson Market Court,
on site of old Jefferson Market.
P.L.Sperr,Photographer.  March 11, 1932.

2
Looking North on Sixth Avenue from 3rd Street.
February 20, 1932.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

Sixth Avenue, east side, from W. 3rd (right) to W. 4th Streets (left),showing this frontage cleared of former buildings. This was necessitated by subway
construction.
The Pepper Pot, a Greenwich Village restaurant is at No. 148 W. 4th Street. View 2 is limited to this feature. This is photographed to outline same against buildings on the opposite side of the street. Note the Washington . E. Church there.
View 1: February 24, 1933
View 2: March 25, 1933
P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - 3rd Street (West).

text:
Sixth Ave., west side, at the head of West 3rd Street, showing the former Lambs Ecclesiastical Art Works being converted into a motion picture theatre. The two frame dwellings, Nos. 14 and 16 Cornelia Street, which are at the rear of this view will be included.
July 10, 1937.
P.L.Sperr.
The Theatre completed.
December 10, 1937.
P.L. Sperr.
A slightly more inclusive view of the same location photographed during the Sixth Avenue 'E1' demolition. Note the iron pillars that formerly supported same in the foreground.
January 17, 1939

P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - 3rd Street (West).

text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, south from W. 3rd Street as viewed from the "El" at that point, showing a play area between same and Bleecker Street. Intersection seen in the immediate foreground is Minetta Lane. Minetta Place, of a quaint Greenwich Village, was formerly in the middle of the block to the south and was eradicated by the extension of Sixth
Avenue.
May 31, 1938.
P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - 3rd Street (West).
